org.apache.juneau.rest

Class RestResponse

  • java.lang.Object
    • javax.servlet.ServletResponseWrapper
      • javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponseWrapper
        • org.apache.juneau.rest.RestResponse
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    HttpServletResponse, ServletResponse

    public final class RestResponse
extends HttpServletResponseWrapper
    Represents an HTTP response for a REST resource.

    Essentially an extended HttpServletResponse with some special convenience methods that allow you to easily output POJOs as responses.

    Since this class extends HttpServletResponse, developers are free to use these convenience methods, or revert to using lower level methods like any other servlet response.

    Example:

    @RestMethod(name="GET") public void doGet(RestRequest req, RestResponse res) { res.setPageTitle("My title") .setOutput("Simple string response"); }

    Refer to REST Servlet API for information about using this class.

      • setOutput

        public RestResponse setOutput(Object output)
        Sets the HTTP output on the response.

        Calling this method is functionally equivalent to returning the object in the REST Java method.

        Can be of any of the following types:

        • InputStream
        • Reader
        • Any serializable type defined in POJO Categories

        If it's an InputStream or Reader, you must also specify the Content-Type using the ServletResponseWrapper.setContentType(String) method.

        Parameters:
        output - The output to serialize to the connection.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setProperty

        public RestResponse setProperty(String key,
                                Object value)
        Add a serializer property to send to the serializers to override a default value.

        Can be any value specified in the following classes:

        • SerializerContext
        • JsonSerializerContext
        • XmlSerializerContext
        Parameters:
        key - The setting name.
        value - The setting value.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

        A map of all the property values set.

      • setOutputs

        public RestResponse setOutputs(Object... output)
        Shortcut method that allows you to use var-args to simplify setting array output.
        Example:

        // Instead of... response.setOutput(new Object[]{x,y,z}); // ...call this... response.setOutput(x,y,z);

        Parameters:
        output - The output to serialize to the connection.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getWriter

        public PrintWriter getWriter()
                      throws IOException
        Returns the writer to the response body.

        This methods bypasses any specified encoders and returns a regular unbuffered writer. Use the getNegotiatedWriter() method if you want to use the matched encoder (if any).

        Specified by:
        getWriter in interface ServletResponse
        Overrides:
        getWriter in class ServletResponseWrapper
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getDirectWriter

        public PrintWriter getDirectWriter(String contentType)
                            throws IOException
        Convenience method meant to be used when rendering directly to a browser with no buffering.

        Sets the header "x-content-type-options=nosniff" so that output is rendered immediately on IE and Chrome without any buffering for content-type sniffing.

        Parameters:
        contentType - The value to set as the Content-Type on the response.
        Returns:
        The raw writer.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getNegotiatedWriter

        public PrintWriter getNegotiatedWriter()
                                throws IOException
        Equivalent to ServletResponse.getWriter(), except wraps the output stream if an Encoder was found that matched the Accept-Encoding header and sets the Content-Encoding header to the appropriate value.
        Returns:
        The negotiated writer.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • sendRedirect

        public void sendRedirect(String uri)
                  throws IOException
        Redirects to the specified URI.

        Relative URIs are always interpreted as relative to the context root. This is similar to how WAS handles redirect requests, and is different from how Tomcat handles redirect requests.

        Specified by:
        sendRedirect in interface HttpServletResponse
        Overrides:

      • setHtmlHeader

        public RestResponse setHtmlHeader(Object value)
        Sets the HTML header section contents.

        The format of this value is HTML.

        The page header normally contains the title and description, but this value can be used to override the contents to be whatever you want.

        A value of "NONE" can be used to force no header.

        This field can contain variables (e.g. "$L{my.localized.variable}").
        See RestContext.getVarResolver() for the list of supported variables.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.header() annotation.

        Parameters:
        value - The HTML header section contents. Object will be converted to a string using Object.toString().

        • Tip: Use StringMessage to generate value with delayed serialization so as not to waste string concatenation cycles on non-HTML views.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlLinks

        public RestResponse setHtmlLinks(String[] value)
        Sets the links in the HTML nav section.

        The format of this value is a lax-JSON map of key/value pairs where the keys are the link text and the values are relative (to the servlet) or absolute URLs.

        The page links are positioned immediately under the title and text.

        This field can contain variables (e.g. "$L{my.localized.variable}").
        See RestContext.getVarResolver() for the list of supported variables.

        A value of "NONE" can be used to force no value.

        This field can also use URIs of any support type in UriResolver.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.links() annotation.

        Parameters:
        value - The HTML nav section links links.

        • Tip: Use StringMessage to generate value with delayed serialization so as not to waste string concatenation cycles on non-HTML views.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlNav

        public RestResponse setHtmlNav(Object value)
        Sets the HTML nav section contents.

        The format of this value is HTML.

        The nav section of the page contains the links.

        The format of this value is HTML.

        When a value is specified, the setHtmlLinks(String[]) value will be ignored.

        This field can contain variables (e.g. "$L{my.localized.variable}").
        See RestContext.getVarResolver() for the list of supported variables.

        A value of "NONE" can be used to force no value.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.nav() annotation.

        Parameters:
        value - The HTML nav section contents. Object will be converted to a string using Object.toString().

        • Tip: Use StringMessage to generate value with delayed serialization so as not to waste string concatenation cycles on non-HTML views.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlAside

        public RestResponse setHtmlAside(Object value)
        Sets the HTML aside section contents.

        The format of this value is HTML.

        The aside section typically floats on the right side of the page.

        This field can contain variables (e.g. "$L{my.localized.variable}").
        See RestContext.getVarResolver() for the list of supported variables.

        A value of "NONE" can be used to force no value.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.aside() annotation.

        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlStylesheet

        public RestResponse setHtmlStylesheet(Object value)
        Sets the CSS URL in the HTML CSS style section.

        The format of this value is a comma-delimited list of URLs.

        Specifies the URL to the stylesheet to add as a link in the style tag in the header.

        The format of this value is CSS.

        This field can contain variables (e.g. "$L{my.localized.variable}") and can use URL protocols defined by UriResolver.
        See RestContext.getVarResolver() for the list of supported variables.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.stylesheet() annotation.

        Parameters:
        value - The CSS URL in the HTML CSS style section. Object will be converted to a string using Object.toString().

        • Tip: Use StringMessage to generate value with delayed serialization so as not to waste string concatenation cycles on non-HTML views.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlTemplate

        public RestResponse setHtmlTemplate(Class<? extends HtmlDocTemplate> value)
        Specifies the template class to use for rendering the HTML page.

        By default, uses HtmlDocTemplateBasic to render the contents, although you can provide your own custom renderer or subclasses from the basic class to have full control over how the page is rendered.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.template() annotation.

        Parameters:
        value - The HTML page template to use to render the HTML page.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setHtmlTemplate

        Specifies the template class to use for rendering the HTML page.

        By default, uses HtmlDocTemplateBasic to render the contents, although you can provide your own custom renderer or subclasses from the basic class to have full control over how the page is rendered.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @HtmlDoc.template() annotation.

        Parameters:

        This object (for method chaining).
